verses.text: Paul, called to be an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, and Sosthenes our brother,
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes his calling as an apostle by divine will, stressing the authoritative nature of his mission. The mention of Sosthenes as 'our brother' highlights unity in the early Church leadership.

verses.text: To the church of God that is in Corinth, to those who are sanctified in Christ Jesus, called to be holy, with all who in every place call on the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, their Lord and ours:
verses.comment: Paul addresses all believers united in Christ and separated for holiness. The assembly's universality and holiness are stressed, foreshadowing later doctrines of the one apostolic church.

verses.text: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Paul’s greeting mirrors the apostolic blessing, showing the twin gifts of grace and peace, from both the Father and Jesus, reflecting Christ’s shared divinity with the Father.

verses.text: I always thank my God for you because of the grace of God that was given to you in Christ Jesus,
verses.comment: Thankfulness is grounded in the grace that believers share in Christ. It is God’s action, not human merit, that gives grace—supporting the importance of divine initiative in salvation.

verses.text: that in every way you were enriched in him, in all speech and all knowledge,
verses.comment: The spiritual gifts of speech and knowledge are emphasized—spiritual richness flows from union with Christ, not from individual achievement, implying the necessity of participating in the life of the Church.

verses.text: even as the testimony about Christ was confirmed among you,
verses.comment: The 'testimony' refers to the preaching and evidence of Christ in the community. The faith is verified by the lived experience and public witness.

verses.text: so that you lack no spiritual gift as you eagerly wait for the revealing of our Lord Jesus Christ,
verses.comment: Paul underlines the fullness of spiritual gifts while believers ‘wait’ for Christ’s coming, referencing the ongoing expectation and hope that shapes the Church’s identity.

verses.text: who will also strengthen you to the end, so that you will be blameless on the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Assurance comes from God’s faithfulness, keeping believers blameless—teaching that perseverance and final justification depend upon continuing in grace, a theme that echoes throughout the New Testament.

verses.text: God is faithful, by whom you were called into the fellowship of his Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.comment: Emphasizes fellowship with Christ, established by God’s faithfulness. Unity with Christ in fellowship is foundational for Christian identity.

verses.text: Now I urge you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be perfectly united in mind and thought.
verses.comment: Paul’s call for unity in doctrine and spirit reveals the early Church’s consistent emphasis on visible unity and agreement among believers—showing the importance of avoiding divisions.

verses.text: For it has been reported to me about you, my brothers, by those of Chloe’s household, that there are quarrels among you.
verses.comment: Factions and disputes disrupt the unity Christ desires for the Church. Reports came through reliable witnesses, demonstrating the value of accountability within the community.

verses.text: What I mean is that each of you says, 'I follow Paul,' or 'I follow Apollos,' or 'I follow Cephas,' or 'I follow Christ.'
verses.comment: The mention of Cephas (Peter) and Christ directly reveals the range of loyalties that existed, and the danger in fracturing the Church’s unity by prioritizing human leaders over Christ.

verses.text: Is Christ divided? Was Paul crucified for you? Or were you baptized in the name of Paul?
verses.comment: Paul uses rhetorical questions to remind them of their allegiance to Christ alone. The reference to baptism highlights the importance and unity of baptism in Christ, not in individual leaders.

verses.text: I thank God that I baptized none of you except Crispus and Gaius,
verses.comment: Paul is relieved not to have contributed to divisions, emphasizing the non-essential role of the apostle as the baptizer, and the primacy of Christ who acts through the sacraments.

verses.text: so that no one may say that you were baptized in my name.
verses.comment: Paul wants no confusion—the authority of baptism is in the name of Christ alone. This anticipates later doctrine that sacraments are effective because of Christ, not the minister.

verses.text: (I did baptize also the household of Stephanas. Beyond that, I do not know whether I baptized anyone else.)
verses.comment: Household baptism suggests the inclusion of entire families—which could include children—in the sacramental life of the Church.

verses.text: For Christ did not send me to baptize but to preach the gospel, and not with eloquent wisdom, lest the cross of Christ be emptied of its power.
verses.comment: Paul's mission focuses on the preaching of the gospel and on the power of the cross, not on human wisdom or the act of baptizing itself. The priority is always on God’s action.

verses.text: For the message of the cross is foolishness to those who are perishing, but to us who are being saved it is the power of God.
verses.comment: Reversal of worldly values: the cross, seen as folly by the world, is the source of true divine wisdom and power. Reference to Isaiah 53 deepens the spiritual understanding of atonement.

verses.text: For it is written: 'I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and the intelligence of the intelligent I will frustrate.'
verses.comment: Paul quotes Isaiah, showing God's pattern of overturning human wisdom. God’s revelation and plan come through humility and apparent weakness.

verses.text: Where is the wise? Where is the scribe? Where is the debater of this age? Has not God made foolish the wisdom of the world?
verses.comment: Paul challenges the supposed wisdom of worldly teachers, aligning with the Old Testament critique of human understanding versus divine truth.

verses.text: For since, in the wisdom of God, the world did not know God through wisdom, it pleased God through the folly of what we preach to save those who believe.
verses.comment: Human wisdom failed to grasp divine saving truth. God’s plan is by faith in the 'foolish' message of Christ crucified.

verses.text: For Jews ask for signs and Greeks seek wisdom,
verses.comment: Different groups look for proof or wisdom, but neither finds their expectations matched in the gospel, which confounds both.

verses.text: but we preach Christ crucified, a stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to Gentiles,
verses.comment: The crucified Messiah defies expectations, fulfilling prophecy yet upending all merely human hope. Paul sees the cross as the center of God's plan.

verses.text: but to those who are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ is the power of God and the wisdom of God.
verses.comment: Jesus is the divine wisdom and power for those who are called, showing a view of salvation working through God’s gracious initiative.

verses.text: For the foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men.
verses.comment: God’s apparent 'folly' and 'weakness' outstrip human strength and understanding—underscoring the paradox of divine wisdom manifested in the cross.

verses.text: For consider your calling, brothers: not many of you were wise according to worldly standards, not many were powerful, not many were noble.
verses.comment: The majority of the Corinthian believers were ordinary people, not from elite backgrounds, showing God’s preference for humility and reversal of worldly expectations.

verses.text: But God chose the foolish things of the world to shame the wise; God chose the weak things of the world to shame the strong;
verses.comment: This reflects God’s habit of exalting the lowly. God’s election overturns human expectations, as seen throughout salvation history.

verses.text: and God chose the low and despised in the world, things that are not, to bring to nothing things that are,
verses.comment: Echoing Mary’s Magnificat, God’s plan subverts the proud and powerful, raising the humble and 'things that are not.'

verses.text: so that no one may boast before God.
verses.comment: Salvation excludes boasting—only God deserves glory. Any claim must defer to divine grace and initiative.

verses.text: But by his doing you are in Christ Jesus, who became for us wisdom from God—and righteousness and sanctification and redemption—
verses.comment: Inspired by Old Testament prophecy, Christ himself is the source of wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption—showing a fullness found in his person and in union with him by faith and sacraments.

verses.text: so, as it is written: 'Let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord.'
verses.comment: Paul closes with Jeremiah’s call to boast only in God, reinforcing the theme that all good comes from union with Christ and the workings of the Spirit through the one true Church.
